metadata.name: Monotipia #73
metadata.description:
Graphic compositions made with simple elements. Playing with the subtlety and rhythm of colors, shapes and textures.

This work was inspired by the textures of monotype prints and those of metal engraving. Especially in the geometric marks made by the inking roller while stretching the graphic ink to make a manual printing. It is a tribute to the visuality of handmade prints.

"Monotipia" means monotype printing in Portuguese. It is a graphic printing process that results in a single copy. Here I make a parallel between monotype printing and the code+hash minting process, which also produces a single image.

---
Features:
-> 15 composition schemes
-> 51 handpicked base colors
-> 3 canvas formats:  
-----> Portrait (vertical) 
-----> Square 
-----> Landscape (horizontal)
-> 3 element tones options: 
-----> Light Texture & Shapes
-----> Light Texture / Dark Shapes 
-----> Dark Texture & Shapes

---
To save the image as a png file, type:
[1] save at actual size 
[2] save with 2000px height
[3] save with 3000px height
[4] save with 4000px height
[5] save with 5000px height

Depending on the size option, the render time can be long.

---
Created with p5.js

---
This is my first project on FX(hash) and I would like to express my special thanks to Janaina Selva, Dmarchi, Gyo and Morbeck for their support and for following the step-by-step development of this work, always contributing with a critical eye and great suggestions. I also thank the help from the FX(hash) community on Discord.

---
(c) Marcelo Terça-Nada, 2023
https://marcelonada.redezero.org/
@marcelonada

metadata.name: Symbologi 01 #221
metadata.description: watch them dance...:-)

metadata.name: Bubblemania #90
metadata.description:
This small project is several things:

1. First and foremost, it's a little, light "visual ASMR" treat to bring some positivity into your day - some "Maluma" softness to contrast the more common "Takete" of contemporary generative art aesthetics[1].

2. A small gift to celebrate the fledgling generative art/design community on Mastodon: 20 of the 128 tokens are given to some of the people in that slowly growing community, with the remainder given as Thank You (and smoke signal/sign of life) to some of my existing collectors, randomly chosen via lottery script[2].

3. For those so inclined, and with a bit of hand-holding, ChatGPT explains the _true_ conceptual depths of this project much better than I ever could:

"The bubbles in this generative art piece serve as a reflection of the human experience, reminding us of our own impermanence and the ephemeral nature of all things. The piece invites us to contemplate the fundamental questions of human existence and speaks to our innate curiosity and desire to understand the world around us.

Through the convergence of science and art, this piece reveals the infinite complexity and unpredictability of the world while also hinting at the underlying order that exists within the chaos of the universe. It reminds us that even in the midst of uncertainty, there is beauty and order to be found, and that it is through the pursuit of knowledge and understanding that we can find meaning and purpose in our lives."

Isn't that lovely & who can argue with that?! :)

4. I often revisit projects/ideas after many years, mainly to re-examine them with new eyes/knowledge/tools and/or to get answers/verification which I couldn't get earlier. This is one of these instances. So for the more rational-minded, this is a TypeScript/GLSL (WebGL) version of an older Clojure/Houdini project (from 2016) to generate a Voronoi via the simulation of intersecting sphere meshes (aka foam bubbles). In this new version the sim & deformations are done in realtime (~4M vertices, mainly via vertex shader). Also added some _basic_ physics and procedural textures to create more of a quirky character (hopefully complemented by the different color themes and other params).

Made with ❤️ and https://thi.ng/umbrella!

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bouba/kiki_effect
[2] https://gist.github.com/postspectacular/3d970e02570b7dfd32d03d43e1e7e3e0

Hotkeys:

SPACE : pause/play
X     : export current frame as PNG

Ultra-widescreen support:

The piece should be adaptive to aspect ratios from 1:3 (portrait) to 4:1 (landscape).

metadata.name: Liminal Slippage #66
metadata.description:
Is this a metaphor of thoughts and perceptions slipping in and out the threshold of the mind? Or colours and shapes bleeding into a virtual focus, gaining grain in the process?

At least we know it's two passes through two different GLSL shaders, where simplex noise is computed and reinterpreted in multiple ways.

Press [spacebar] to toggle play/pause.

When paused, press [p] to create hi-res PNG.

metadata.name: Radiant #133
metadata.description:
We were all born with a jewel in our heart – golden, shining.  Maybe you call it love, or the divine, or beauty.  The trials of life can cover up that jewel, and make it hard to see the beauty within.  We think we’re not worthy, not lovable.  But that’s a lie.  The jewel is always there.  You just need to clean off the gunk.  We are all made of love and supernovas.  You always were, and always will be - radiant.

Radiant was created generatively in p5.js.  Seven possible radial designs overlap on two canvases. On the top canvas, circles or arcs are erased to reveal the canvas below. There are four ways the background gets created, mostly using Perlin noise to pick colors from the palette. There are 34 hand-crafted palettes of 7 colors each. 

Original pixel density 1 with grain added automatically.
After pressing “open”:
2 – 5 to increase pixel density.  
g to add grain.  Adding grain takes a while at pixel density 5.
s to save a png.
Screen resize renders at pixel density 1.

I love sharing what I’ve learned about gen art and inspiring others on my YouTube channel, Steve’s Makerspace. Follow me there and on Twitter @stevemakerspace and Mastodon @stevesmakerspace.

metadata.name: Angular View #48
metadata.description:
The angle factor plays a significant role in determining how an image feels and looks.
When viewed from one angle, elements inside the frame might appear compressed and unclear, while when viewed from another angle, they might appear clear and distinct.
Choosing the right angle can encourage and guide the audience, while choosing the wrong angle can confuse and mislead him.
Therefore, when choosing the angle, one should consider aesthetic, technical, and emotional factors to present the subject to the viewer in the best light.
Depending on the angle, space and subject of the image are transformed and they can convey various meanings, including: logical visualization of space/impossible and free visualization, exaggeration and exaggeration/simplicity, stillness/movement, insider/alienation, mysterious/reliable, and complexity.
Made by p5.js
s = save

metadata.name: Aging and Forgotten #57
metadata.description:
"Aging and Forgotten" is my tribute to the transience of technology and life. In this exhibit, I bring together a collection of discarded technological devices and symbols of aging and death, such as skulls and bones. My goal is to create a powerful commentary on the impermanence of all things and the parallel between the aging of technology and the aging of people. Through the combination of technology and the human, I invite viewers to reflect on their own experiences of aging, loss, and the passage of time. With "Aging and Forgotten," I aim to challenge viewers to consider the impact of our rapidly advancing technology and the ultimate fate of all things, both human and technological.

- look for the gold mode
- press p to export png
- press s to export svg

metadata.name: Contraformas #35
metadata.description:
Shapes are drawn on a space-filling grid against other shapes, using a random walk algorithm. then they are separated with a random offset, hence the name counterforms (contraformas).

created by @mdollinger with p5js

metadata.name: BLOCK PARTY #221
metadata.description:
A generative algorithm exploring isometric grids and recursive divisions with an emphasis on contrasting colors.

A random rectange division is so simple yet creates vastly different and interesting outputs.

An isometric grid provides a unique perspective to the recursion giving each piece a certain depth and contrast.

When does chaotic randomness become beauty and what interesting patterns may emerge?

Press 's' in live mode to save image. Best viewed after save.

* Original code by Matt Lehoullier with p5.js

metadata.name: Monotipia #13
metadata.description:
Graphic compositions made with simple elements. Playing with the subtlety and rhythm of colors, shapes and textures.

This work was inspired by the textures of monotype prints and those of metal engraving. Especially in the geometric marks made by the inking roller while stretching the graphic ink to make a manual printing. It is a tribute to the visuality of handmade prints.

"Monotipia" means monotype printing in Portuguese. It is a graphic printing process that results in a single copy. Here I make a parallel between monotype printing and the code+hash minting process, which also produces a single image.

---
Features:
-> 15 composition schemes
-> 51 handpicked base colors
-> 3 canvas formats:  
-----> Portrait (vertical) 
-----> Square 
-----> Landscape (horizontal)
-> 3 element tones options: 
-----> Light Texture & Shapes
-----> Light Texture / Dark Shapes 
-----> Dark Texture & Shapes

---
To save the image as a png file, type:
[1] save at actual size 
[2] save with 2000px height
[3] save with 3000px height
[4] save with 4000px height
[5] save with 5000px height

Depending on the size option, the render time can be long.

---
Created with p5.js

---
This is my first project on FX(hash) and I would like to express my special thanks to Janaina Selva, Dmarchi, Gyo and Morbeck for their support and for following the step-by-step development of this work, always contributing with a critical eye and great suggestions. I also thank the help from the FX(hash) community on Discord.

---
(c) Marcelo Terça-Nada, 2023
https://marcelonada.redezero.org/
@marcelonada

metadata.name: - Satellites - #54
metadata.description:
-Satellites-

The Space Probe project was humanity's bold endeavor to explore the universe beyond our own solar system. At the height of the space race between the years 2400 and 2500, hundreds of probe satellites were sent out into the unknown, each with a unique mission to collect data on distant galactic objects and search for signs of life and habitable planets.
As the probes ventured to the edge of the solar system and beyond, they extended humanity's reach and understanding of the universe. Many of these probes were equipped with the ability to communicate their findings back to Earth, allowing us to delve deeper into the mysteries of the cosmos.
The probes took many forms, including galactic probes, communication satellites, and planetary probes designed for sample return. As they floated in the vast wasteland that surrounds the Milky Way galaxy, these probes searched for organic molecules, the building blocks of life, and conducted their missions with determination.
Although some of the probes have since become redundant, they continue to float through the void, reminders of humanity's unending quest for knowledge and discovery in the universe. The Space Probe project was a landmark achievement, pushing the boundaries of human understanding and paving the way for further exploration of the cosmos.

X to toggle the Animation (on/off)
R to reset

Build with WebGL
Gert-Jan Akerboom - 2023

(20% of primary sales will go to girlswhocode.com)
